@dongeforever : Thanks for the finding. Great catch. The patch looks good. Perhaps we could add a comment in ConnectionState about state transition (e.g., we can transition from any of CONNECTING, CHECKING_API_VERSIONS, READY directly to DISCONNECTED).
@guozhangwang Do you think @hachikuji's suggestion to change max.poll.records won't work?

Will leave this for @guozhangwang to review. I think I am not fully convinced of the value of logging _every_ error response at info level. The risk of overwhelming the logs seems high. I would prefer to do response-level logging in the clients if possible. That said, if Guozhang is ok with it, then so am I.
@guozhangwang Yes they are. I pushed a fix.

OK. The way I see things, we always have `grep -v` to remove the lines which don't interest us. However, if the log level was not set to debug at the time of an incident, we will have no option but to set it to debug level and hope the issue reproduces. 

If I had to choose between these two options, I would choose `grep -v` any day. 

This is especially true for  a new feature which is not going to be heavily used in the medium term, but is likely to face the highest number of issues within the first months of release. Having verbose logging for such a thing has very little downside and a big upside IMO.

Yes, tuning the log level for a new feature is definitely a challenge. That's why I'm deferring to Guozhang since he would know better than I which log messages will be most helpful to debug TC problems. I think, however, that it's a mistake to view this only from the perspective of what's useful to us. Obviously all logging is helpful to us to debug problems, but it puts a burden on users who who have to try to separate signal from noise without knowledge of the implementation details. And response-level logging is particularly risky when we don't know how often some of these scenarios will actually be hit in practice.

> We could simply pass a flag to the appendTransactionToLog method.

I have thought about that too. The reason I did not follow that is because we would want to add the check on the cached metadata anyways when the append fails, and if the metadata has changed we would just want to abort transiting.
